{{Infobox NFL_season | logo = [[File:AaronRodgersGBPackers.svg|125px]] | team = Green Bay Packers | year = 2007 | record = 13-3 | division_place = 1st [[NFC North]] | coach = [[Mike McCarthy (American football)|Mike McCarthy]] | stadium = [[Lambeau Field]] | playoffs = '''Won''' [[NFL playoffs, 2007-08|Divisional Playoffs]]
Lost NFC Championship (New York Giants) }} The '''[[2007 NFL season|2007]] [[Green Bay Packers]] season''' was the franchise's 89th overall and 87th season in the [[National Football League]]. The Packers finished the regular season with an impressive 13-3 record. They received a [[Bye (sports)|bye]] for the first round of the [[NFL playoffs, 2007â08|playoffs]], won their divisional round playoff game, and lost in the [[NFC Championship]] game to the eventual [[Super Bowl]] champion [[New York Giants]]. This was the last season for quarterback [[Brett Favre]] as a Green Bay Packer. This season also marked the 50th anniversary of the opening of the Packers' home stadium of [[Lambeau Field]]. The Packers' tenure at Lambeau, now at 52 seasons, is the longest in NFL history at a single stadium, breaking the [[Chicago Bears]]' previous record of 50 seasons at [[Wrigley Field]] (1921â1970). == Offseason == On February 2, 2007, [[Brett Favre]] announced that he would return for the 2007 season. "I am so excited about coming back," the 37-year-old quarterback said on the website of ''[[The Sun Herald]]'' in [[Biloxi]], [[Mississippi]]. He also commented, "We have a good nucleus of young players. We were 8-8 last year, and that's encouraging."{{cite web | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/GB/9970509 | title = Packers' Favre to play in 2007 | publisher = NFL.com | date = 2007-02-02 | accessdate = 2007-02-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070203235520/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/GB/9970509 |archivedate = 2007-02-03}}{{cite web | url = http://packers.com/news/releases/2007/02/02/1/ | title = Favre to return in 2007 | publisher = Packers.com | date = 2007-02-02 | accessdate = 2007-02-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070204013335/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/02/02/1/ |archivedate = 2007-02-04}}{{cite web | url = http://www.sunherald.com/fmld/sunherald/16607933.htm | title = Favre to play in 2007 | work = The Sun Herald | date = 2007-02-02 | accessdate = 2007-02-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Ted Thompson, Green Bay's general manager, confirmed the news, saying, "The Packers are excited by his decision and look forward to a successful 2007 campaign."{{cite web | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/GB/9970509 | title = Favre to return for 17th season | publisher = NFL.com | date = 2007-02-02 | accessdate = 2007-02-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070203235520/http://www.nfl.com/teams/story/GB/9970509 |archivedate = 2007-02-03}} This would be, however, Brett Favre's last season with the Packers. === 2007 NFL draft === The [[2007 NFL Draft]] occurred on April 28-29. The Packers picked 16th overall, selecting [[defensive tackle]] [[Justin Harrell]] in the first round.{{cite web | url = http://www.nfldraftcountdown.com/features/draftorder.html | title = 2007 NFL Draft Order | publisher = NFLDraftCountdown.com | accessdate = 2007-02-03| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiT7Q1YY | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} {| class="wikitable" |+ 2007 Packers Draft Selections ! (compensatory) || [[Clark Harris]] || [[Tight end]] || [[Rutgers]] |} Reportedly, the Packers were in talks with [[Oakland Raiders]] wide receiver [[Randy Moss]] at the behest of Brett Favre.{{cite web | url = http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/sports/16655406.htm | title = Randy Moss would fit with Favre and Packers | publisher = mercurynews.com | work = [[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]] | last = Hunt | first = Michael | date = 2007-02-08 | accessdate = 2007-02-11| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiT8ByM9 | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} If the Packers had made the move to acquire the 30 year-old [[wide receiver]], the trade would no doubt have been a controversial one, as Moss has a long and storied history with the Green Bay franchise. While Moss's salary was high, Green Bay, at the time, reportedly had $24 million of cap space, and could have absorbed his contract easily.{{cite web | url = http://nfl.com/news/story/9988414 | title = With games over, it's down to business | last = Kirwan | first = Pat | publisher = NFL.com | date = 2007-02-13 | accessdate = 2007-02-13 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070220000304/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/9988414 |archivedate = 2007-02-20}} These rumors were put to an end on 29 April 2007, when Oakland dealt Moss to New England for a 4th round draft pick.{{cite web | url = http://nfl.com/nflnetwork/story/10156954 | title = Raiders send WR Moss to Patriots | publisher = NFL.com | last = Schefter | first = Adam | date = 2007-04-29 | accessdate = 2007-04-29 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070501031922/http://nfl.com/nflnetwork/story/10156954 |archivedate = 2007-05-01}} In the days following the NFL draft, Favre was upset concerning Green Bay's inability to acquire Moss.{{cite web | url = http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/6805790?MSNHPHMA | title = Favre asked for trade after draft | last = Glazer | first = Jay | publisher = Fox Sports | date = 2007-05-14 | accessdate = 2007-05-15| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiT8l4BS | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Favre was reportedly so upset that his agent requested that the Packers trade him. Coach Mike McCarthy was able to calm Favre down over the phone, and Favre eventually admitted that while he wanted to win, he did not want to be traded in order to do so. ===Departures=== On March 5, the Texans signed running back [[Ahman Green]] to a contract.{{cite web | url = http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=572985 | title = Greener Pastures | last = Silverstein | first = Tom | publisher = JS Online | date = 2007-03-04 | accessdate = 2007-04-29| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiT9a7eC | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} On March 5, the Dolphins signed tight end [[David Martin (American football)|David Martin]] to a contract.{{cite news | url = http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/story/2007/03/05/nfl-dolphins-martin.html | title = Adding David Martin among Dolphins' moves | publisher = CBC Sports | date = 2007-03-05 | accessdate = 2007-04-29| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiT9k0D7 | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} On March 7, the Packers cut fullback [[William Henderson (American football)|William Henderson]].{{cite web | url = http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=574864 | title = Packers cut Henderson | last = Silverstein | first = Tom | publisher = JS Online | date = 2007-03-07 | accessdate = 2007-04-29 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070320141254/http://www.jsonline.com/story/index.aspx?id=574864 |archivedate = 2007-03-20}} ===Free agents heading into the 2007 season=== {| class="wikitable" |- !Position || Player || [[Free agent|Free agency]]

Eagles=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Eagles |R1=0||R2=10||R3=3||R4=0||RT=13 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=10||H2=0||H3=3||H4=3||HT=16 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/12:00 PM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= 62Â°Â°F(16.7 Â°C) (Cloudy) |attendance= 70,598 |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football official)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]] (play-by-play), [[Daryl Johnston]] (color commentator), & [[Tony Siragusa]] (sideline reporter) }} The Packers began their season at home against the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. In the first quarter, Green Bay's [[Jarrett Bush]] recovered the Eagles' [[Greg Lewis (wide receiver)|Greg Lewis]]'s muffed punt in the end zone for a touchdown. The contest was tied in the closing minutes but the Eagles again muffed a punt return, setting up a 42-yard game-winning kick from Packers rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]]. This was the only game the Packers did not score an offensive touchdown. Crosby was named NFC Special Teams Player of the Week.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/12/3/ | title = Mason Crosby Named NFC Special Teams Player of the Week | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-10-04 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080115161602/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/12/3/ |archivedate = 2008-01-15}} Crosby is the only player in league history to boot a 50-plus yard field goal and game-winning field goal in the final minute in his first NFL game.{{cite web | url = http://www.madison.com/tct/sports/264614 | title = Packers: Consistent Crosby keeps on course | publisher = Madison.com | accessdate = 2007-12-29| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTANGf4 |archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} ===Week 2: at New York Giants=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=0||R2=7||R3=7||R4=21||RT=35 |Home=Giants |H1=0||H2=10||H3=3||H4=0||HT=13 |stadium= [[Giants Stadium]], [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 64 Â°F (Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 78,701 |referee= [[Gene Steratore]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Joe Buck]] (play-by-play), [[Troy Aikman]] (color commentator), & [[Pam Oliver]] (sideline reporter) }} [[File:GBNYShotgun.jpg|thumb|right|The Packers in the [[shotgun formation|shotgun]]]] Playing a close game until the fourth quarter, the Packers took a commanding lead late in the game (racking up 21 points in the final fifteen minutes) and winning the game 35-13. Early in the 4th quarter, Favre capped off a drive with a pass to the outside of the endzone to Donald Lee, and then followed it up with a 10-yard pass to Donald Driver by the goalpost for a score after the Giants fumbled the ensuing kickoff deep in their own territory. In the victory, Brett Favre threw for 286 yards and 3 touchdowns and gave him his 149th career win as a starter, the most by any [[quarterback]] in NFL history, surpassing [[John Elway]]. Favre was named NFC Offensive Player of the Week for games played September 16-17.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/19/5/ | title = Brett Favre Named NFC Offensive Player Of The Week | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-09-28 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071226181953/http://packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/19/5/ |archivedate = 2007-12-26}} Mike McCarthy was voted the Motorola NFL Coach of the Week.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/21/2/ | title = Mike McCarthy Named NFL Coach Of The Week | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-10-04 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080115161607/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/21/2/ |archivedate = 2008-01-15}} {{-}} ===Week 3: vs. San Diego Chargers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Chargers |R1=7 |R2=7 |R3=7 |R4=3 |RT=24 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=3 |H2=14 |H3=0 |H4=14 |HT=31 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 10:00 a.m. PDT/12:00 p.m. [[Central Time Zone (North America)|CDT]] |weather= 73 Â°F (Sunny) |attendance= 70,733 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Jim Nantz]] (play-by-play) & [[Phil Simms]] (color commentator) }} Quarterback Brett Favre threw three touchdown passes against the [[San Diego Chargers|Chargers]] in the victory, bringing his career total to 420 and tying [[Dan Marino]]'s career touchdown record. With just over two minutes remaining in the game and San Diego leading 21-17, Favre found wide receiver [[Greg Jennings]] for a 57-yard catch-and-run across the middle of the field for the go ahead score. On the Chargers ensuing drive, linebacker Nick Barnett intercepted a [[Philip Rivers]] pass and returned it to the San Diego 1-yard line setting up the Packers final score and a 10 point lead. Barnett was voted the GMC Defensive Player of the Week for games played on September 23 - 24.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/27/1/ | title = Nick Barnett Named Defensive Player Of The Week | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-10-04|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080124145316/http%3A//www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/27/1/ |archivedate = January 24, 2008|deadurl=yes}} This win made the Packers the only team to have missed the playoffs the previous season to return to open 3-0 against teams that made the playoffs the year before.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/23/1/printable/ | title = Packers-Chargers Press Box Notes | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-01-06|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080724153636/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/09/23/1/printable/ |archivedate = July 24, 2008|deadurl=yes}} ===Week 4: at Minnesota Vikings=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=7 |R2=3 |R3=3 |R4=10 |RT=31 |Home=Vikings |H1=0 |H2=6 |H3=3 |H4=7 |HT=24 |stadium= [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]], [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] |time= 1:05 P.M. EDT/12:05 P.M. CDT |weather= Indoors |attendance= 63,779 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Ron Pitts]] (play-by-play) and [[J.C. Pearson]] (color commentator) }} [[File:09.30.07 favre 421TD.JPG|thumb|[[Brett Favre]] broke [[Dan Marino]]'s TD pass record during Week 4 at the HHH Metrodome]] Coming off their home win over the Chargers, the Packers flew to the [[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]] for an NFC North division game against [[Minnesota Vikings|Minnesota]]. In the first quarter, QB [[Brett Favre]] threw a 16-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Jennings]] surpassing [[Dan Marino]] as the league's all-time leader in touchdown passes. He also became the league leader in pass attempts (8,393 at game's end).{{cite web | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/recap?gameId=270930016 | title = Favre's record-setting day helps Green Bay stay perfect | publisher = sports.espn.go.com | accessdate = 2007-11-02| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTAsYVk | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Favre was named the NFC Offensive Player of the Week for the second time this season, having thrown for 344 yards and two touchdowns.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/10/03/4/ | title = Brett Favre Named NFC Offensive Player Of The Week. | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-10-04 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071008193245/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/10/03/4/ |archivedate = 2007-10-08}} With the win, the Packers stayed undefeated and improved to their first 4-0 start since 1998.{{cite news | url = http://www.spokesmanreview.com/sports/story.asp?ID=212492 | title = Packers 4-0 | agency = Associated Press | accessdate = 2007-11-02}} {{-}} ===Week 5: vs. Chicago Bears=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bears''' |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=10 |R4=10 |RT=27 |Home=Packers |H1=7 |H2=10 |H3=3 |H4=0 |HT=20 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 8:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/7:15 PM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= 79 Â°F (Cloudy) |attendance= 70,904 |referee= [[Larry Nemmers]] |TV=[[NBC]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Al Michaels]] (play-by-play), [[John Madden (American football)|John Madden]] (color commentator), & [[Andrea Kramer]] (sideline reporter) }} Coming off a record-setting divisional road game against the Vikings, the Packers went home for a Sunday night divisional clash with their arch-nemesis, the [[Chicago Bears]]. This would be the 174th meeting between the two teams. In the first quarter, Green Bay got off to a fast start by capping off the game's opening drive with rookie RB [[DeShawn Wynn]] getting a 2-yard TD run for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, the Bears tied the game with RB [[Cedric Benson|Cedric Benson's]] 10-yard TD run. The Packers would end the first half with QB [[Brett Favre]] completing a 41-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Jennings]], along with rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]] converting a 37-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Chicago crept closer with kicker [[Robbie Gould]] converting a 44-yard field goal. Green Bay responded with Crosby kicking a 37-yard field goal, yet the Bears pulled to within three as QB [[Brian Griese]] completed a 19-yard TD pass to TE [[Greg Olsen (American football)|Greg Olsen]]. In the fourth quarter, Chicago erased their deficit completely with Gould's 36-yard field goal and Griese's 34-yard TD pass to TE [[Desmond Clark]]. With a turnover-plagued loss (5 turnovers on the night), the Packers fell to 4-1. Also, with two interceptions, Favre tied QB [[George Blanda]] at 277 for the most career interceptions. {{cite web | last = Walter | first = David | title = Mistakes hurt Packers in first loss of the season | url=http://www.sportsnetwork.com/default.asp?c=sportsnetwork&page=/nfl/news/ABN4106874.htm | accessdate = 2006-04-30 }} {{dead link|date=July 2011}} Also of note, [[Brady Poppinga]] intercepted a pass in the fourth quarter, extending the streak of at least one Packer interception per game for the 11th consecutive game. This matched the longest streak in team history, which occurred during an 11 game stretch in 1984-1985. {{cite web | last=Calhoun | first=George | authorlink=George Calhoun | title=The Dope Sheet | volume=IX | issue=11 | page=2 | date=October 9, 2007 | url=http://www.packers.com/pdfs/07dopesheet_vs_was.pdf |format=PDF | postscript=}} {{dead link|date=February 2011}} ===Week 6: vs. Washington Redskins=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Redskins |R1=7 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=27 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=7 |H2=0 |H3=10 |H4=0 |HT=20 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |weather= 47 Â°F (rain) |attendance= 70,761 |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]] (play-by-play) and [[Troy Aikman]] (color commentator). [[Pam Oliver]] was the sideline reporter. }} On October 14, 2007 [[Charles Woodson]] picked up a [[Santana Moss]] fumble and returned it 57 yards for a go ahead touchdown in a 17-14 victory over the [[Washington Redskins]].NFL, [http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/nfl/stories/101507dnsponflredskins.22851d9.html Woodson returns fumble for touchdown as Packers beat Redskins, 17-14], October 14, 2007 {{Wayback|url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/nfl/stories/101507dnsponflredskins.22851d9.html|date =20071015113741}} He also recorded an interception in the game, his first of the season. This was the 12 straight game that Green Bay has recorded an interception, making it a new team record surpassing an 11 game stretch in 1984-1985.{{cite web | last = Fly | first = Colin | title = Despite surprising start, Packers trying to stay grounded with 5-1 record | url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/cpress/20071020/ca_pr_on_fo/nfl_packers_bye_1 | accessdate = 2007-10-21}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} In the third quarter, former Redskins safety [[Sean Taylor]] intercepted a Brett Favre pass making Favre the career interception leader in NFL history, eclipsing George Blanda's record of 277 interceptions. Favre threw two interceptions for the game. {{cite web | last = Associated Press | title = Woodson returns fumble for touchdown as Packers beat Redskins, 17-14 | url=http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/nfl/stories/101507dnsponflredskins.22851d9.html | accessdate = 2007-10-14 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071015113741/http%3A//www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/nfl/stories/101507dnsponflredskins.22851d9.html |archivedate = October 15, 2007|deadurl=yes}} Woodson was named the NFC's Defensive Player of the Week for his performance versus the Redskins. It was the first time he has received this award.{{cite web | last = Associated Press | title = Packers' Woodson Wins NFC's Defensive Player Of Week| url=http://www.channel3000.com/sports/14363376/detail.html?rss=c3k&psp=news | accessdate = 2007-10-21| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTCa6vW | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} With the win, the Packers entered its bye week at 5-1. ===Week 8: at Denver Broncos=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=7 |R2=6 |R3=0 |R4=0 |R5=6 |RT=19 |Home=Broncos |H1=7 |H2=0 |H3=3 |H4=3 |H5=0 |HT=13 |stadium= [[Invesco Field at Mile High]], [[Denver, Colorado]] |time= 8:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] ([[Monday Night Football]]) |weather= {{convert|67|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}}, (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 77,160 |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[ESPN]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Mike Tirico]] (play-by-play), [[Ron Jaworski]], [[Tony Kornheiser]] (color commentators), [[Michele Tafoya]], & [[Suzy Kolber]] (sideline reporters) }} Following their bye week, the Packers flew to Denver to take on the Broncos on [[Monday Night Football]]. In the first quarter, Bronco quarterback [[Jay Cutler (American football)|Jay Cutler]] opened the scoring with a 5 yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Tony Scheffler]]. On the first play of the ensuing series [[Brett Favre]] completed a 79 yard touchdown to rookie wide receiver [[James Jones (wide receiver)|James Jones]]. In the second quarter, rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]] converted a 19 yard field goal, followed by a 26 yard field goal, and the Packers took a 13-7 lead into halftime. In the third quarter, Broncos kicker [[Jason Elam]] converted a 45 yard field goal to cut Green Bay's lead to 3 points. In the fourth quarter, after getting the ball back with 2:27 remaining in the game, Cutler led a drive that began on the Bronco seven yard line down the length of the field to the Green Bay four yard line. On a 3rd and 1 Cutler attempted a quarterback draw to win the game, but [[Ryan Pickett]] stopped Cutler for no gain on the play. With no time outs remaining Elam and the kicking unit ran onto the field and converted a field goal to tie the game on the final play of the quarter. [[Greg Jennings]] called heads and won the overtime coin toss, allowing Green Bay to receive the ball to begin overtime. On the first play, Favre threw an 82 yard touchdown pass to Jennings, who had outrun Bronco cornerback [[DrÃ© Bly]] for the catch. This was Favre's 13th TD pass of 75 yards or more, most of any player in NFL history.{{cite web | last=Calhoun | first=George | authorlink=George Calhoun | title=The Dope Sheet | volume=IX | issue=14 | page=2 | date=October 30, 2007 | url=http://www.packers.com/pdfs/071030_atChiefs.pdf|format=PDF | postscript=|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080724211445/http://www.packers.com/pdfs/071030_atChiefs.pdf |archivedate = July 24, 2008|deadurl=yes}} Favre also becomes the first Packers player to throw two touchdown passes of 75 yards or more in the same game. Only three quarterbacks have accomplished the feat since 1990. [[Ryan Grant]] ran for 104 yards, the first Packer to break the 100 yard rushing mark this season. With the win (their first ever in Denver), the Packers improved to 6-1. On November 1, 2007 [[Aaron Kampman]] was named the NFC Defensive Player of the Month for October, having recorded 5.5 sacks during that time period.{{cite web | title = Jacobs, Kampman and Akers nab NFC monthly awards | url=http://www.nbc15online.com/sports/nfl/story.aspx?content_id=2d266496-a0dd-4ce3-868a-26e1c24d3555 | accessdate = 2007-11-02}} {{dead link|date=February 2011}} Brett Favre was voted the Fedex Air and Ground NFL Player of the Week award for games played on October 28 - 29, the third time this season he has received this award.{{cite web | title = Brett Favre Named FedEx Air Player Of The Week | url=http://packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/01/2/ | accessdate = 2007-11-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071103064133/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/01/2/ |archivedate = 2007-11-03}} Wide receiver James Jones of the Packers was announced as the Diet Pepsi 2007 Rookie of the Week for games played on October 28-29. Jones made three receptions for 107 yards including a first-quarter 79-yard touchdown.{{cite web | title = James Jones Named NFL Rookie Of The Week | url=http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/02/2/ | accessdate = 2007-11-03 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071107064453/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/02/2/ |archivedate = 2007-11-07}} ===Week 9: at Kansas City Chiefs=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=0 |R2=6 |R3=7 |R4=20 |RT=33 |Home=Chiefs |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=0 |H4=15 |HT=22 |stadium= [[Arrowhead Stadium]], [[Kansas City, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]]/12:00 PM [[Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= 61 Â°F (Clear skies) |attendance= 78,988 |referee= [[Walt Anderson (American football official)|Walt Anderson]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Joe Buck]] (play-by-play), [[Troy Aikman]] (color commentator), & [[Pam Oliver]] (sideline reporter) }} Coming off their Monday Night road win over the Broncos, the Packers flew to [[Arrowhead Stadium]] for a Week 9 interconference duel with the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] (the only team that QB [[Brett Favre]] had never beaten). After a scoreless first quarter, Green Bay drew first blood with rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]] getting a 48-yard and a 36-yard field goal. However, the Chiefs would take the lead into halftime as RB [[Larry Johnson (American football)|Larry Johnson]] completed a 1-yard TD run. In the third quarter, the Packers regained the lead as Favre completed a 13-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Jennings]] for the only score of the period. In the fourth quarter, Kansas City regained the lead with QB [[Damon Huard]] completing a 30-yard TD pass to Johnson. Green Bay replied with Crosby kicking a 32-yard field goal, yet the Chiefs answered with Huard completing a 17-yard TD pass to TE [[Tony Gonzalez (tight end)|Tony Gonzalez]] (with RB [[Priest Holmes]] getting the 2-point conversion run). The Packers pulled back into the lead as Favre and Jennings hooked up again on a 60-yard TD pass. Afterwards, Crosby made a 45-yard field goal, and CB [[Charles Woodson]] returned an interception 46 yards for a touchdown. With the win, the Packers improved to 7-1. The Packers scored 17 points in the final 3:05 on a defense that hadn't given up more than 20 all year.{{cite web | last = Associated Press | title = Favre magical again, leads comeback against Chiefs | url=http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/recap?game_id=29314&displayPage=tab_recap&season=2007&week=REG9 | accessdate = 2007-11-04| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTEhAOm | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Favre joined [[Peyton Manning]] and [[Tom Brady]] as quarterbacks who've beaten all 31 other teams in the NFL. Favre rallied the Packers to victory from a fourth-quarter deficit or tie for the fourth time this season and 40th in his career, second only to John Elwayâs 46 fourth-quarter comebacks.{{cite web | last = Covitz | first = Randy | title = Favre adds to his historic totals in his first win against the Chiefs | url=http://www.kansascity.com/sports/chiefs/story/346792.html | accessdate = 2007-11-05|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071105234908/http%3A//www.kansascity.com/sports/chiefs/story/346792.html |archivedate = November 05, 2007|deadurl=yes}} The Packers have won 11 of their last 12 games, dating back to last season. Their sixth straight road wins tie for the second-longest away-from-home streak in team history.{{cite web | last = Associated Press | title = Packers win battle of first place teams | url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/7400078?CMP=OTC-K9B140813162&ATT=5 | accessdate = 2007-11-04| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTFFrzp | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} ===Week 10: vs. Minnesota Vikings=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Vikings |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=0 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=7 |H2=6 |H3=14 |H4=7 |HT=34 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/12:00 PM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= {{convert|49|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} |attendance= 70,945 |referee= [[Gerald Austin|Gerry Austin]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] (play-by-play), [[Brian Baldinger]] (color commentator) }} Playing their first home game since mid-October, the Packers hosted their division rivals, the [[Minnesota Vikings]]. In the first half, the first career touchdown{{cite news | last = USA Today | title = Adrian Peterson injures knee in loss to Green Bay | url=http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/vikings/2007-11-11-peterson-injured_N.htm | accessdate = 2007-11-11 | date=2007-11-12| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTFK50o | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} by [[Ryan Grant]] came on a 30-yard run and gave the Packers a 7-0 lead, and two field goals by Mason Crosby (a 39-yard field goal midway through the 2nd quarter and a 24-yard field goal at the end of the half) would provide all the first half scoring, as the Packers went to the locker room leading 13-0. In the 2nd half, Brett Favre threw a pair of third quarter touchdown passes, one to Donald Lee and one to Ruvell Martin (which was Favre's 200th TD pass at Lambeau Field),{{cite web | last = Sporting Life | title = Packers crush vikings | url=http://www.sportinglife.com/nfl/news/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=international_feed/07/11/11/GRIDIRON_USA-Green_Bay_Nightlead.html | accessdate = 2007-11-11| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTFzoPu | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} giving the Packers a 27-0 lead. With an additional Martin touchdown catch in the 4th quarter, the Packers shutout the Vikings 34-0, their first shutout of 2007. The Packers defense held [[Adrian Peterson]] to a season-low 45 yards on 11 carries a week after he set the NFL single-game rushing record with 296 yards against the San Diego Chargers.{{cite web | last = Bloomberg | title = Green Bay Favre Has Three Touchdowns for Packers: NFL Week 10 (Update1) | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079&sid=atEyDv6WWymc&refer=home | accessdate = 2007-11-11| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTGulSW | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Grant became the first running back to reach the century mark against the Vikings this season, rushing for 119 yards on 25 carries, his career best. With the win, the Packers improved to 8-1, which matches the best start to a season in Brett Favre's career (in 1996 and 2002). This game was the first time the Vikings have been shutout since 1991,{{cite web | last = Associated Press | title = Peterson sprains knee, Packers shutout Vikings, 34-0 | url=http://www.kare11.com/news/ts_article.aspx?storyid=269385 | accessdate = 2007-11-11}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and halted the Vikingsâ NFL-record run of 260 consecutive regular-season games with a point.{{cite web | last = Souhan | first=Jim | title = Vikings thoroughly embarrassed in Green Bay | url=http://www.lacrossetribune.com/articles/2007/11/12/sports/1sports12.txt| accessdate = 2007-11-12}} {{dead link|date=February 2011}} The game was Green Bay's first shutout of the Vikings in 94 games of the rivalry.{{cite web | last = Korth | first= Todd| title = Packers whip Vikings, 34-0 | url=http://chi.scout.com/a.z?s=25&p=2&c=700565 | accessdate = 2007-11-11| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTHamec | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} During the game, Favre became only the second NFL quarterback to throw for 60,000 yards in a career. He now has 60,257 yards' passing in his 17-year NFL career, second only to Dan Marino's career passing record of 61,361 yards.{{cite web | last = The Canadian Press | title = Green Bay Packers rough up Adrian Peterson in 34-0 win over Vikings | url=http://canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5iHzmqluXhTGEi-N6qIeQc3vhXgFw | accessdate = 2007-11-11|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071114010057/http%3A//canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5iHzmqluXhTGEi-N6qIeQc3vhXgFw |archivedate = November 14, 2007|deadurl=yes}} On November 15, 2007 the NFL announced Brett Favre and running back Ryan Grant were voted the FedEx Air & Ground NFL Players of the Week for games played on November 11 - 12.{{cite web | title = Favre, Grant Named FedEx Air & Ground NFL Players Of The Week | url=http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/15/3/ | accessdate = 2007-11-16 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071119003814/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/15/3/ |archivedate = 2007-11-19}} Favre has received the Fedex Air award four times this season. Coach McCarthy was voted the Motorola NFL Coach of the Week for games played on November 11 - 12, the second time he has received the award this season.{{cite web | title = FavreMike McCarthy Named NFL Coach Of The Week | url=http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/16/2/ | accessdate = 2007-11-19|archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080516151953/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/16/2/ |archivedate = May 16, 2008|deadurl=yes}} ===Week 11: vs. Carolina Panthers=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Panthers |R1=3 |R2=0 |R3=7 |R4=7 |RT=17 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=7 |H2=14 |H3=7 |H4=3 |HT=31 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/12:00 PM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= 42 Â°F |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Dick Stockton]] (play-by-play) & [[Brian Baldinger]] (color commentator) |attendance= 70,805 |referee= [[Gene Steratore]] }} 38-year-old Brett Favre faced off against 44-year-old Carolina quarterback [[Vinny Testaverde]] in a game that featured the oldest starting quarterbacks duo in NFL history.{{cite web | last = Jenkins | first= Chris | title = Green Bay 31, Carolina 17 | url=http://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/recap?gid=20071118009 | accessdate = 2007-11-18}} Favre threw 3 touchdown passes, and [[Tramon Williams]] returned a punt 94-yard for another touchdown as Green Bay defeated the [[Carolina Panthers]] 31-17. It was Favre's 62nd career game with at least three touchdown passes, tying [[Dan Marino|Dan Marino's]] record. The win moved Green Bay to 9-1 on the season, its best start through the first 10 games since 1962. This is also Favre's best 10 game start to a season in his career.{{cite web | last = STATS Inc. | title = STATS INC: Week 11 pregame notes | url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/7446378 | accessdate = 2007-11-19| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTIrVkZ | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Packers punt returner Tramon Williams was named Special Teams Players of the Week for games played the 11th week of the 2007 season (November 18-19).{{cite web | last = Packers.com | title = PR Tramon Williams Named NFC Player Of The Week | url=http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/21/2/ | accessdate = 2007-11-22 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071217084306/http://packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/21/2/ |archivedate = 2007-12-17}} Packers defensive tackle [[Corey Williams (football player)|Corey Williams]] was voted the GMC Defensive Player of the Week for games played on November 18-19. Williams posted four solo tackles, two sacks and two forced fumbles during the game.{{cite web | last = Packers.com | title = Corey Williams Named Defensive Player Of The Week | url=http://packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/22/3/ | accessdate = 2007-11-29 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071217084311/http://packers.com/news/releases/2007/11/22/3/ |archivedate = 2007-12-17}} ===Week 12: at Detroit Lions=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=0 |R2=17 |R3=14 |R4=6 |RT=37 |Home=Lions |H1=6 |H2=3 |H3=3 |H4=14 |HT=26 |stadium= [[Ford Field]], [[Detroit, Michigan]] |time= 12:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/11:30 AM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= 68 Â°F |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Joe Buck]] (play-by-play), [[Troy Aikman]] (color commentator), & [[Pam Oliver]] (sideline reporter) |attendance= 63,257 |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] }} Coming off their home win over the Panthers, the Packers flew to [[Ford Field]] for a Week 12 Thanksgiving NFC North duel with the [[Detroit Lions]]. Lions kicker [[Jason Hanson]] completed a 47-yard field goal, and followed it with a 41-yarder to give the Lions a 6-0 lead after the first quarter. [[Brett Favre]] started the second quarter with an 11 yard TD pass to [[Greg Jennings]]. The Packers held on to the lead for the remainder of the game, winning 37-26. The win moved the Packers to 10-1 on the season. Favre finished the game with 3 touchdowns, the 63rd time he has thrown 3 or more touchdowns in a game, breaking the record he held with [[Dan Marino]]. At one point during the game, Favre completed 20 consecutive passes, breaking the Packers team record of 18 (held by [[Don Majkowski]] and [[Lynn Dickey]]).{{cite web | last = Sporting Life | title = Packers continue superb start | url=http://www.sportinglife.com/story_get.cgi?STORY_NAME=international_feed/07/11/22/manual_213433.html| accessdate = 2007-11-22| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTIzczz | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Favre threw for 381 passing yards, which was his seventh 300-yard passing game of the season, tying a career high.{{cite web | last = Bensch | first = Bob | title = Favre Leads Packers Over Lions 37-26 for Sixth-Straight Victory | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601079&sid=aOGPTfBupG5g&refer=home | accessdate = 2007-11-22| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTJy5YW | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} For his performance, Favre was awarded Fox's Galloping Gobbler Award. Favre also was voted Fedex Air NFL Player of the Week, the fifth time this year he has received the award.{{cite web | last = National Football League | title = Favre, Gore named Week 12 FedEx Air and Ground NFL Players of the Week | url=http://www.nfl.com/partner?partnerType=players-air-and-ground| accessdate = 2007-11-30| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5mqszucVX | archivedate = 2010-01-17| deadurl=no}} Green Bay has equaled its best 11-game record since 1929.{{cite web | last = Korth | first = Todd | title = Packers stave off hungry Lions, 37-26 | url=http://gnb.scout.com/2/704489.html | accessdate = 2007-11-22| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTK5ovL | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} With the win, the Packers improved to 10-1 (the team's best start since 1962). ===Week 13: at Dallas Cowboys=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Packers |R1=10 |R2=7 |R3=7 |R4=3 |RT=27 |Home='''Cowboys''' |H1=13 |H2=14 |H3=0 |H4=10 |HT=37 |stadium= [[Texas Stadium]], [[Irving, Texas]] |time= 8:15 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/7:15 PM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= 56 Â°F (Clear) |TV=[[NFL Network]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Bryant Gumbel]] (play-by-play) and [[Cris Collinsworth]] (color commentator) |attendance= 64,167 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] }} Coming off their Thanksgiving win over their divisional foe, the Lions, the Packers flew to [[Texas Stadium]] for a Week 13 Thursday night intraconference duel with the throwback-clad [[Dallas Cowboys]]. This match-up would see two 10-1 teams face one another for the first time since 1990 when the [[New York Giants]] lost to the [[San Francisco 49ers]].{{cite news | url = http://www.latimes.com/sports/motorracing/la-sp-briefing25nov25,1,6288379.story?coll=la-headlines-sports-autoracing&ctrack=1&cset=true | title = Not perfect, but 10 isn't bad number | publisher = LA Times | accessdate = 2007-11-26}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} Cowboys quarterback [[Tony Romo]] faced off against his boyhood idol [[Brett Favre]] in the game.{{cite news | url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/nfl/cowboys/2007-11-26-romo-wisconsin_N.htm | title = Romo remembers Wisconsin roots in test with Packers | publisher = USA Today | + accessdate = 2007-11-26 | date=2007-11-27 | accessdate=2010-04-22 | first1=Pete | last1=Dougherty | first2=Green | last2=Bay| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTKsnaP | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} The Packers started the game missing two key players of their defense, with injured cornerback [[Charles Woodson]] (tied for 7th in the NFL with 4 interceptions) and pass-rushing end [[Kabeer Gbaja-Biamila]] (tied for 6th in the NFL with 9.5 sacks) on the inactive list.{{cite news | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/11/29/AR2007112902609.html?hpid=moreheadlines | title = Favre Gets Hurt, Cowboys Get Ahead | publisher = Washington Post | accessdate = 2007-11-30 | first=Mark | last=Maske | date=2007-11-30| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTLJpzC | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} In the first quarter, Green Bay took the early lead as rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]] completed a 47-yard field goal. On the first play of the Cowboys opening drive, Al Harris stripped the ball from Terrell Owens and side judge [[Laird Hayes]] signaled Green Bay ball, but head linesman Derick Bowers overruled him. The only option for [[Mike McCarthy (American football)|Mike McCarthy]] to challenge on the play, since the whistle was blown, was whether it was a reception - the strip could not be reviewed. The replay upheld the reception and Dallas retained possession.{{cite web | last = Banks | first = Don | url = http://www.packersnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071130/PKR0201/711300656/1989 | title = Notebook: Woodson, KGB injuries hurt 'D' | publisher = Packers News | accessdate = 2007-11-30| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTMNUTa | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}}{{cite news | url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/writers/don_banks/11/29/snap.judgments/1.html | title = Favre's bad night, cable wars, Barber, T.O. and more | publisher = Sports Illustrated | accessdate = 2007-11-30 | date=2007-11-30| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTMXr2h | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}}{{cite web | url = http://www.footballoutsiders.com/print/5827/ | title = Audibles at the Line: Packers at Cowboys | publisher = football outsiders| accessdate = 2007-11-30}} {{dead link|date=February 2011}}{{cite web | last = Wilde | first=Jason | url = http://www.madison.com/wsj/home/sports/index.php?ntid=259758&ntpid=3 | title = Left guard still not right | publisher = Wisconsin State Journal | accessdate = 2007-12-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite web | last = Pelissero | first=Tom | url = http://www.packersnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071205/PKR01/712050554/1989 | title = Notebook: QB NallâIt's 'great to be back' | publisher = PackersNews.com| accessdate = 2007-12-05| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTO7hdF | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Nick Folk completed a 26-yard field goal to tie the game. Folk also completed a 51-yard field goal, and QB [[Tony Romo]] threw a 3-yard TD pass to WR [[Patrick Crayton]]. The Packers would end the first quarter with rookie RB [[Ryan Grant]] running for a 62-yard touchdown. In the second quarter, Dallas responded with Romo completing a 26-yard TD pass to TE [[Anthony Fasano]] and a 10-yard TD pass to WR [[Terrell Owens]]. [[Brett Favre]] left the game in the second quarter after he hit his right elbow on the helmet of a blitzing Cowboys DB [[Nate Jones (American football)|Nate Jones]]. The throw led to Favre's second interception. Packers quarterback [[Aaron Rodgers]] took over for the Packers next series and led the offense on a 74-yard drive, capping it off with an 11-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Jennings]]. In the third, Grant finished off a 69-yard Packer drive with a 1-yard TD run for the only score of the quarter. In the fourth quarter, Romo completed a 4-yard TD pass to Crayton. Mason Crosby kicked a 52-yard field goal with just over 5 minutes remaining in the game to pull the Packers within a field goal. Dallas sealed the win as Folk kicked a 25-yard field goal with 1:03 left in the game. The Packers were flagged for a season-high 142 penalty yards. With the loss, the Packers move to 10-2. ===Week 14: vs. Oakland Raiders=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Raiders |R1=0||R2=7||R3=0||R4=0||RT=7 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=0||H2=14||H3=17||H4=7||HT=38 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]]/12:00 PM [[Central Time zone|CDT]] |weather= 18 Â°F (Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 70,828 |referee= [[Ed Hochuli]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] (play-by-play) & [[Rich Gannon]] (color commentator) }} Hoping to rebound from their Thursday night road loss to the Cowboys, the Packers went home for Favre's 250th (270th including playoffs) consecutive start,{{cite news | url = http://www.usatoday.com/sports/football/2007-12-09-2027733741_x.htm | title = In 250th straight start, Packers' Favre is effective, unspectacular | publisher = USA Today.com | last = Fly | first = Colin | date = 2007-12-09 | accessdate = 2007-12-10| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTPXwn4 | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} along with Green Bay's Week 14 interconference duel with the [[Oakland Raiders]]. After a scoreless first quarter, the Packers sliced away in the second quarter with rookie RB [[Ryan Grant]] getting a 6-yard TD run, while CB [[Will Blackmon]] returned a punt 57 yards for a touchdown. The Raiders would end the half with their only score of the game as QB [[Josh McCown]] completed a 25-yard TD pass to WR [[Jerry Porter (American football)|Jerry Porter]]. In the third quarter, Green Bay took control with rookie [[Mason Crosby]] nailing a 44-yard field goal, QB [[Brett Favre]] completing an 80-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Jennings]], while Blackmon recovered an Oakland fumble in their endzone for a touchdown (making him the first player since Cincinnati's [[Lemar Parrish]] in 1974 to return a punt and a fumble for a touchdown in one game). In the fourth quarter, the Packers pulled away with Favre completing a 46-yard TD pass to TE [[Donald Lee (American football)|Donald Lee]]. With the win, not only did Green Bay improve to 11-2, but they also clinched the NFC North division title.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/stories/2007/12/09/5/ | title = Game Review: Division Title is First Step | publisher = Packers.com | last = Spofford | first = Mike | date = 2007-12-09 | accessdate = 2007-12-10 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071212070048/http://www.packers.com/news/stories/2007/12/09/5/ |archivedate = 2007-12-12}} It was the Packers' 18th division title, along with their 24th playoff berth with three games remaining in the season - the second-fastest division title in team history.{{cite web | url = http://www.madison.com/wsj/home/sports/index.php?ntid=261221 | title = Packers: Easy win wraps up NFC North title | publisher = Wisconsin State Journal | last = Wilde | first = Jason | date = 2007-12-09 | accessdate = 2007-12-10 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071211182403/http://www.madison.com/wsj/home/sports/index.php?ntid=261221 |archivedate = 2007-12-11}} Blackmon was awarded NFC Special Teams Player of the Week honors for his performance.{{cite web | url = http://www.sportsnetwork.com/default.asp?c=sportsnetwork&page=/nfl/news/ABN4117155.htm | title = Collins, Trufant and Blackmon earn NFC weekly honors | publisher = The Sports Network | date = 2007-12-12 | accessdate = 2007-12-12| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTRMGpI | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} ===Week 15: at St. Louis Rams=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Packers''' |R1=7||R2=10||R3=10||R4=6||RT=33 |Home=Rams |H1=7||H2=7||H3=0||H4=0||HT=14 |stadium= [[Edward Jones Dome]], [[St. Louis, Missouri]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= Game Played Indoors (Domed Stadium) |attendance= 66,008 |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]] (play-by-play), [[Daryl Johnston]] (color commentator), & [[Tony Siragusa]] (sideline reporter) }} Coming off their dominating home win over the Raiders, the Packers flew to the [[Edward Jones Dome]] for a Week 15 duel with the [[St. Louis Rams]]. In the first quarter, Green Bay drew first blood as rookie RB [[Ryan Grant]] got a 1-yard TD run. Afterwards, the Rams responded with QB [[Marc Bulger]] completing a 4-yard TD pass to WR [[Torry Holt]]. In the second quarter, Green Bay went back into the lead as QB [[Brett Favre]] completing a 4-yard TD pass to TE [[Donald Lee (American football)|Donald Lee]], yet St. Louis answered with RB [[Steven Jackson]] getting a 46-yard TD run. The Packers would regain the lead prior to halftime with rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]] getting a 44-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Green Bay took control as Crosby kicked a 50-yard field goal, along with Favre completing a 44-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Jennings]]. In the fourth quarter, the Pack finished the Rams off with Crosby nailing a 25-yard and a 46-yard field goal. With the win, the Packers improved to 12-2. Brett Favre came into the contest needing 184 yards to break [[Dan Marino]]'s all-time record mark of 61,361 career passing yards. He broke the record, as he threw for 227 total yards in the game. The new record came on a seven yard completion to [[Donald Driver]]. [[Ryan Grant]] and [[Greg Jennings]] each had a touchdown during the game, making it the first time two Packers players have each scored a touchdown in the same four consecutive games.{{cite web | last=Goska | first=Eric | url = http://www.packersnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071217/PKR07/712170567/1989 | title = Eric Goska column: Grant-Jennings scoring streak sets team record | publisher = Packersnews.com | accessdate = 2007-12-17| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTSFqRQ | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} [[Atari Bigby]] was voted the GMC Defensive Player of the Week for games played on December 13 - 17. Bigby made four tackles and two interceptions (a career high). Bigby intercepted the ball on the Packers' 22-yard line late in the second quarter to keep the Packers ahead by three going into halftime.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/12/20/2/ | title = Atari Bigby Voted Defensive Player Of The Week | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-12-23 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080223062734/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/12/20/2/ |archivedate = 2008-02-23}} Kicker Mason Crosby was voted the Diet Pepsi NFL Rookie of the Week for games played on December 13 - 17. Crosby went four-for-four in field goals, including a long 50-yard field goal and 46-yard and 44-yard kicks, and three-for-three in extra points.{{cite web | url = http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/12/21/2/ | title = Mason Crosby Voted NFL Rookie Of The Week | publisher = Packers.com | accessdate = 2007-12-23 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20071225050248/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2007/12/21/2/ |archivedate = 2007-12-25}} With the [[Carolina Panthers]] defeating the [[Seattle Seahawks]] on the day, the Packers clinched a first round bye for the playoffs. ===Week 16: at Chicago Bears=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Packers |R1=0||R2=7||R3=0||R4=0||RT=7 |Home='''Bears''' |H1=3||H2=10||H3=15||H4=7||HT=35 |stadium= [[Soldier Field]], [[Chicago, Illinois]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= {{convert|16|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} (Wind chill: {{convert|-1|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} Winds: 30-40 mph gusts) |attendance= 62,272 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Joe Buck]] (play-by-play), [[Troy Aikman]] (color commentator), & [[Pam Oliver]] (sideline reporter) }} In cold and windy conditions, [[Brett Favre]] threw 2 interceptions, and the Bears blocked 2 punts, en route to a 35-7 victory over the Packers, giving the Bears a sweep against Green Bay for the 2007 season. The Packers had not had a punt blocked in 12 years (929 punts).{{cite web | url = http://www.canada.com/reginaleaderpost/news/sports/story.html?id=a4b8f194-cde1-4a43-b798-16240c3f1b91 | title = Ryan wants to forget Bears game | publisher = The Leader Post| accessdate = 2007-12-26| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTSLdxV | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} The last time the Packers had 2 punts blocked in a game was September 21, 1975 in a game against Detroit.{{cite web | url = http://www.post-trib.com/sports/710878,bearsnotes.article | title = NFL: Special use of weather aids punt-block team| publisher = Post Tribune | accessdate = 2007-12-26}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Favre ended the game with 158 passing yards, and he surpassed 4,000 yards passing for the season, the 5th time in his career to achieve the mark. [[Ryan Grant]] ran for 100 total yards and the only touchdown for the Packers. With the loss, the Packers fell to 12-3 on the season. ===Week 17: vs. Detroit Lions=== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Lions |R1=3||R2=7||R3=3||R4=0||RT=13 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=14||H2=7||H3=10||H4=3||HT=34 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= {{convert|19|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} |attendance= 70,869 |referee= [[Pete Morelli]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]] (play-by-play), [[Daryl Johnston]] (color commentator), & [[Tony Siragusa]] (sideline reporter) }} [[Brett Favre]] left less than a minute into the second quarter with the game well in hand, as he had thrown two touchdown passes, and running back [[Ryan Grant]] had another one on a 27 yard run. Backup quarterback [[Craig Nall]] threw another touchdown in his first playing time in the NFL since 2004. Packers punter [[Jon Ryan]] had a 72-yard punt in the fourth quarter, the longest punt at Lambeau Field since 1965.{{cite web | url = http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter?season=2007&week=REG17&game_id=29440| title = Green Bay rolls over Detroit | publisher = NFL.com| accessdate = 2007-12-30| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTUPkSd | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} Running back [[Brandon Jackson (running back)|Brandon Jackson]] topped the 100 yard mark for the first time in his career, running for 113 yards.{{cite web | url = http://www.madison.com/wsj/home/sports//index.php?ntid=264752 | title = Running in relief a thriller for Jackson | publisher = Wisconsin State Journal | accessdate = 2007-01-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Packers rookie kicker [[Mason Crosby]] finished the season leading the NFL with 141 points, the highest-scoring season by a kicker in franchise history and third-highest season point total by any Packers player.{{cite news | last= Jenkins | first=Chris | url = http://news.yahoo.com/s/cpress/20071230/ca_pr_on_fo/nfl_det_gb_4 | title = Green Bay Packers prepare for playoffs with 34-13 victory over Lions | agency = Associated Press | accessdate = 2008-01-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Green Bay has 17 consecutive home victories over Detroit, a team that has not recorded a victory in Wisconsin since 1991.{{cite web | last= Cotsonika| first=Nicholas| url = http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071231/SPORTS01/712310347 | title = Green Bay had nothing to gain, still dominated Lions to win 17th straight in Wisconsin | publisher = Free Press | accessdate = 2008-01-01}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} With their 5th straight win over the [[Detroit Lions|Lions]], the Packers finished the season with a record of 13-3. The 13-win season was the fourth in the history of the Packer team (1997, 1996, and 1962 were the others). On January 2, 2008 Brandon Jackson was voted NFL Rookie of the Week for games played December 29-30, 2007. Jackson ran the ball 20 times for 113 yards and made two receptions for 22 yards in the Packers' 34 - 13 win over the Detroit Lions.{{cite web |last= Packers.com | title = RB Brandon Jackson Voted NFL Rookie Of The Week | url=http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2008/01/02/2/| accessdate = 2008-01-02 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080105031913/http://www.packers.com/news/releases/2008/01/02/2/ |archivedate = 2008-01-05}} On January 3, 2008 the NFL announced McCarthy finished second in voting for [[National Football League Coach of the Year Award|The Associated Press 2007 NFL Coach of the Year]], garnering 15 votes to [[Bill Belichick|Bill Belichick's]] leading 29 votes.{{cite web |last= Associated Press | title = Unbeaten regular season lifts Belichick to second AP Coach of Year honor | url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d805b47b4&template=without-video&confirm=true | accessdate = 2008-01-03 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080104153614/http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d805b47b4&template=without-video&confirm=true |archivedate = 2008-01-04}} == Playoffs == {{main|NFL playoffs, 2007-08}} ===Schedule=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Playoff Round || Date || Opponent (seed) || Result || Record || Game Site || NFL Recap || TV |- style="text-align:center;" | Wild Card || colspan="8" style="text-align:center;"| ''[[Bye (sports)|Bye]]'' |- style="background:#dfd;" | align=center| '''Divisional''' | January 12, 2008 | '''[[2007 Seattle Seahawks season|Seattle Seahawks]] (3)''' | style="text-align:center;"| '''W''' 42-20 | style="text-align:center;"| 14-3 | [[Lambeau Field]] | [http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/recap?game_id=29520&displayPage=tab_recap&season=2007&week=POST19&override=true Recap] | Fox |- style="background:#fdd;" | align=center| '''NFC Championship''' | January 20, 2008 | '''[[2007 New York Giants season|New York Giants]] (5)''' | style="text-align:center;"| '''L''' 23-20 (OT) | style="text-align:center;"| 14-4 | [[Lambeau Field]] | [http://www.nfl.com/gamecenter/recap?game_id=29525&displayPage=tab_recap&season=2007&week=POST20&override=true Recap] | Fox |} === Divisional Round: Seattle Seahawks === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Seahawks |R1=14||R2=3||R3=3||R4=0||RT=20 |Home='''Packers''' |H1=14||H2=14||H3=7||H4=7||HT=42 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 4:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 28Â°F (heavy snow) |attendance= 72,168 |referee=[[Mike Carey (American football official)|Mike Carey]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]] (play-by-play), [[Daryl Johnston]] (color commentator), & [[Tony Siragusa]] (sideline reporter) }} [[Mike Holmgren]] and the [[Seattle Seahawks]] played the Green Bay Packers for a chance to play in the NFC Championship game. The Packers beat the Seahawks 42-20. [[Ryan Grant]] fumbled twice in the first 69 seconds, the turnovers led to an early 14-0 Seahawk lead. Grant redeemed himself by running for 201 yards and three touchdowns - both franchise play-off records (Ahman Green had run for 156 yards in a 2004 playoff game).{{cite web | last = Cooney | first=Bill | title = Packers 42, Seahawks 20: From Grant's tomb to Ryan's hope | url=http://www.madison.com/wsj/mad/sports/index.php?ntid=267032 | accessdate = 2008-01-13| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTVtLd1 | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} [[Brett Favre]] went 18-for-23 for 173 yards and three touchdowns, two to [[Greg Jennings]], joining [[Joe Montana]] as the only passers in league history with 5,000 yards in postseason play.{{cite news | last = Biggs | first=Brad | title = Favre plows ahead | url=http://www.suntimes.com/sports/739037,CST-SPT-pack13.article | accessdate = 2008-01-13}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} Other Packer team records set during the game include most points in a game with 42, most touchdowns with six, and most first downs with 25.{{cite web | last = Thiel | first=Art | title = This was humiliation, pure and simple | url=http://www.seattlepi.com/football/347175_thiel13.html | accessdate = 2008-01-13| archiveurl = http://www.webcitation.org/5wiTVzkoi | archivedate = 2011-02-23| deadurl=no}} === NFC Championship: New York Giants === {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Giants''' |R1=3||R2=3||R3=14||R4=0||R5=3||RT=23 |Home=Packers |H1=0||H2=10||H3=7||H4=3||H5=0||HT=20 |stadium= [[Lambeau Field]], [[Green Bay, Wisconsin]] |time= 6:30 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= -1Â°F (-20Â° to {{convert|-40|Â°F|Â°C|abbr=on}} windchill) |attendance= 72,740 |referee=[[Terry McAulay]] |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] | TVAnnouncers= [[Joe Buck]] (play-by-play), [[Troy Aikman]] (color commentator), [[Chris Myers]] and [[Pam Oliver]] (field reporters) }} The Green Bay Packers were defeated by the New York Giants at Lambeau Field in overtime. It was the 3rd coldest game in NFL history. Favre extended his NFL record to 18 straight playoff games with at least one touchdown pass. It came on a 90 yard touchdown throw to [[Donald Driver]], the longest playoff pass in Packers team history.{{cite web | last = Wilner | first=Barry | title = Another Manning headed to Super Bowl | url=http://www.seattlepi.com/football/2021ap_fbn_nfc_championship.html?source=mypi | accessdate = 2008-01-24}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} This would also be the final game in Favre's legendary career as a Green Bay Packer. ==Season statistical leaders== * Passing Yards: [[Brett Favre]] 4,155 Yards * Passing Touchdowns: Brett Favre 28 TD * Rushing Yards: [[Ryan Grant]], 956 Yards * Rushing Touchdowns: [[Ryan Grant]], 8 TD * Receiving Yards: [[Donald Driver]], 1,048 Yards * Receiving Touchdowns: [[Greg Jennings]], 12 TD * Points: [[Mason Crosby]], 141 points * Kickoff Return Yards: [[Tramon Williams]], 684 Yards * Punt Return Yards: [[Charles Woodson]], 268 Yards * Tackles: [[Nick Barnett]], 131 Tackles * Sacks: [[Aaron Kampman]], 12 Sacks * Interceptions: [[Atari Bigby]], 5 Interceptions ==Awards and records== ===Awards=== * [[Brett Favre]] was named [[Sports Illustrated]] Sportsman of the Year. * Brett Favre was named [[FedEx]] Air Player of the Year. * Brett Favre was awarded Fox's Galloping Gobbler Award. * Brett Favre was voted 5x for the FedEx Air NFL Player of the Week. * [[Mason Crosby]] was named NFC Special Teams Player of the Week for games played on Week 1. * Brett Favre was named NFC Offensive Player of the Week for games played September 16-17 * [[Mike McCarthy (American football)|Mike McCarthy]] was voted the Motorola NFL Coach of the Week for games played on September 16-17. * [[Nick Barnett]] was voted the GMC Defensive Player of the Week for games played on September 23 - 24. * Brett Favre was named the NFC Offensive Player of the Week for games played on Week 4. * [[Charles Woodson]] was named the NFC's Defensive Player of the Week for games played on Week 6. * [[Aaron Kampman]] was named the NFC Defensive Player of the Month for October. * [[James Jones (wide receiver)|James Jones]] was announced as the Diet Pepsi 2007 Rookie of the Week for games played on October 28-29. * Mike McCarthy was voted the Motorola NFL Coach of the Week for games played on November 11 - 12. * [[Tramon Williams]] was named Special Teams Players of the Week for games played on November 18-19. * [[Corey Williams (American football)|Corey Williams]] was voted the GMC Defensive Player of the Week for games played on November 18-19. * [[Will Blackmon]] was awarded NFC Special Teams Player of the Week honors for games played on Week 14. * [[Atari Bigby]] was voted the GMC Defensive Player of the Week for games played on December 13 - 17. * [[Mason Crosby]] was voted the Diet Pepsi NFL Rookie of the Week for games played on December 13 - 17. * [[Brandon Jackson (running back)|Brandon Jackson]] was voted NFL Rookie of the Week for games played December 29-30. * Atari Bigby was voted NFC Defensive Player of the Month for games played in December. * [[Chris Francies]] was the winner of the Packers' [[Ed Block Courage Award]]. * Mike McCarthy was voted 2007 NFL Alumni's Coach of the Year. * Mike McCarthy was voted 2007 Motorola NFL Coach of the Year. ===Records=== ====Individual==== * [[Brett Favre]] surpassed [[John Elway]] as the leagues's all-time leader in career wins as a starter. * Brett Favre surpassed [[Dan Marino]] as the league's all-time leader in touchdown passes. * Brett Favre set the league record for most pass attempts in a career. * Brett Favre surpassed [[George Blanda]] as the league's all-time leader in intereceptions thrown. * Brett Favre set the league record for the most career touchdown passes of 75 yards or more. * Brett Favre joined [[Tom Brady]] and [[Peyton Manning]] as the only quarterbacks who've beaten all 31 other teams in the NFL. * Brett Favre surpassed [[Dan Marino]] as the league's all-time leader in career 3 touchdown games. * Brett Favre surpassed [[Don Majkowski]] and [[Lynn Dickey]] setting the Packers record of most consecutive completions in a game with 20. * Brett Favre surpassed himself setting the Packers record for Highest Completion Percentage, Season (140 att.) with 66.54%. * Brett Favre tied [[Don Majkowski]] for the team record of Most Attempts, No Interceptions, Game with 46 vs. Min on November 11, 2007. * [[Will Blackmon]] became only the second player in league history to return a punt and a fumble for a touchdown in the same game. * Brett Favre surpassed [[Dan Marino]] as the league's all-time leader in career passing yards. * Brett Favre joined [[Joe Montana]] as the only passers in league history to eclipse 5,000 passing yards in career postseason play. * [[Mason Crosby]] lead the NFL in points scored with 141. * Mason Crosby broke the team record of Most Points, No Touchdowns, Season with 141. * Mason Crosby broke the team record of Most Points, Rookie, Season with 141. * [[Ryan Grant]] broke the franchise playoff rushing yards in playoff game record with 201 yards against the [[Seattle Seahawks]]. * Ryan Grant broke the franchise rushing touchdowns in a playoff game record with 3 touchdowns against the [[Seattle Seahawks]]. * [[Nick Barnett]] tied [[Brian Noble (American football)|Brian Noble]] and [[Bernardo Harris]] for the team record of, Tackles,Most Seasons Leading Team (1975-2007) with 4. ====Team==== * Most Games Won, Regular Season: 13 (1962, 1996, 1997 also won 13) * Most First Downs Allowed By Penalty, Season: 44 * Most First Downs, Passing, Game: 22 vs. Minnesota, November 11, 2007 * Most Games, 300 Net Yards Passing, Season: 7 * Most Consecutive Games, 300 Net Yards Passing: 3 (twice) (1984, 2004 also had 3 consecutive) * Highest Completion Percentage, Season: 66.26% (383 completions in 578 attempts) * Most TD, Opponents' Fumbles Recovered, Season: 3 (2004 also had 3) ===2008 Pro Bowl selections=== The Packers had five [[2008 Pro Bowl]] selections, 9th most in the NFL.
